componenttext: Great. Great. That's very helpful. And then just as a follow-up. I mean, I think in the past, you've talked about community count rising low single digits. As you pivot to selling homes a little bit later, is there any change to that estimate or it's intact?

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our goal, as we focus on gaining market share, consolidating market share, we would expect over the longer term, higher community count to continue to grow, obviously, today with the strong demand, but there are some communities where we have sold out soo
componenttext: Our goal, as we focus on gaining market share, consolidating market share, we would expect over the longer term, higher community count to continue to grow, obviously, today with the strong demand, but there are some communities where we have sold out sooner. And so you see some quarterly fluctuation in that. But over the longer term, we'd expect the trend to be for community counts to continue to grow at a modest pace at a low to mid-single-digit pace over the longer term.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next questions come from the line of Truman Patterson with Wolf Research.
componenttext: Our next questions come from the line of Truman Patterson with Wolf Research.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: So first question on -- you alluded in your press release about double-digit unit growth into 2022. And my question doesn't really pertain to demand or the demand outlook really, but I'm just hoping to understand what are some of the biggest risks to achi
componenttext: So first question on -- you alluded in your press release about double-digit unit growth into 2022. And my question doesn't really pertain to demand or the demand outlook really, but I'm just hoping to understand what are some of the biggest risks to achieving that growth on the supply side. We've heard issues with lot development availability, community approvals, material shortages, a little bit of labor issues. I'm just hoping that you can explain some of these risks that might impede that double-digit growth and how some of those constraints you see playing out into '22.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: Truman, it's really is a little bit of everything you mentioned, but it's nothing new. It's all things, as Mike said earlier on, we've been working through this entire time. So if we didn't feel confident in the double digit and the ability to continue to
componenttext: Truman, it's really is a little bit of everything you mentioned, but it's nothing new. It's all things, as Mike said earlier on, we've been working through this entire time. So if we didn't feel confident in the double digit and the ability to continue to manage through those and ramp up our production to more adequately meet the demand that's in the market, we wouldn't be saying that here in July. But there are constraints, and we wouldn't say it's any one thing. It's everything you outlined and it varies by market, essentially on a daily basis, what the constraint is, but our operators are doing a fantastic job of navigating through that.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: But the positioning we can see in our inventory, our inventory did increase by about 1,000 units this quarter, up 44% over the year-over-year. On a trailing 12-month basis, we've started 94,500 homes. That in and of itself is double-digit growth over what
componenttext: But the positioning we can see in our inventory, our inventory did increase by about 1,000 units this quarter, up 44% over the year-over-year. On a trailing 12-month basis, we've started 94,500 homes. That in and of itself is double-digit growth over what our planned deliveries are this year. So we're already in position to deliver double digit and working to improve on that and expand on that as we move into '22. So we feel like we're in a great position to do that. There will be challenges. There will be unknown challenges that we haven't dealt with yet, but we're confident in our teams and our ability to continue to maintain the current pace and incrementally improve on it as we move into '22 on our starts.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: And I know that's a relatively high-level comment today. We're sitting in July. We haven't finished our fiscal year. So we would expect in November to give more specific guidance in addition to just the double-digit closing target.
componenttext: And I know that's a relatively high-level comment today. We're sitting in July. We haven't finished our fiscal year. So we would expect in November to give more specific guidance in addition to just the double-digit closing target.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: Okay. Really, what I'm kind of looking at is on the material side, we've heard of shortages kind of across the board, but especially windows, doors concrete. I mean it depends which market, right? But do you actually have contracts in place with your supp
componenttext: Okay. Really, what I'm kind of looking at is on the material side, we've heard of shortages kind of across the board, but especially windows, doors concrete. I mean it depends which market, right? But do you actually have contracts in place with your suppliers to actually get that level of product?

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: We have relationships with our suppliers. I mean no matter what the contract says, you're going to get what they're going to give you and they're going to deliver who they want to deliver to. And so we work very hard to be a good trade partner with our su
componenttext: We have relationships with our suppliers. I mean no matter what the contract says, you're going to get what they're going to give you and they're going to deliver who they want to deliver to. And so we work very hard to be a good trade partner with our suppliers in both materials and labor and making sure they understand what our production plans are and our commitment is to them, and they've made the commitments to us.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: Again, it goes back to scale within these markets. I mean, we're a very important customer to just about every material supplier in those markets. So Mike's right, it is about relationships, but it's about future relationships as well. So is it going to b
componenttext: Again, it goes back to scale within these markets. I mean, we're a very important customer to just about every material supplier in those markets. So Mike's right, it is about relationships, but it's about future relationships as well. So is it going to be difficult? Absolutely. It's going to be difficult because they're saying no to somebody. We just don't want them to be saying no to us.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then my follow-up question, just a follow-up, very strong order ASP quarter-over-quarter. We've just seen a lot of builders starting to employ a final and best bidding process. Just hoping to understand either what portion of your communit
componenttext: Understood. And then my follow-up question, just a follow-up, very strong order ASP quarter-over-quarter. We've just seen a lot of builders starting to employ a final and best bidding process. Just hoping to understand either what portion of your communities or the portion of that price hike came from the bidding process. And then on the other side of it, just with affordability, there's been some talk -- some believe in the industry that there's been some incentives picking up. Have you seen that in any of your local markets?

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: Certainly haven't seen any incentives ticking up. And we have used the [ fund ] to invest in certain communities and where we have a very limited lot supply. But that's not a giant component of what we're seeing in sales price or margin. It certainly is i
componenttext: Certainly haven't seen any incentives ticking up. And we have used the [ fund ] to invest in certain communities and where we have a very limited lot supply. But that's not a giant component of what we're seeing in sales price or margin. It certainly is impactful and it certainly happened in our extended longer communities especially at the price points we have -- we're offering in the entry level. We don't like that -- I personally don't like that process because. In 506, there was a false demand by people running around putting houses on the contract that they never intended to close. I don't want our operators to have a false expectation about the pricing that's achievable in the market by having a guy from California bid on a house and stuff, look on a guy in Texas. And then all of a sudden, every house is worth what a guy transferring in from California is willing to pay. We're trying to stay very close to these markets. And our goal is to -- everybody walks into our house all into our model -- into our home. And we're not there right now, but we're certainly going to get to that.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021

componenttext: Our next questions come from the line of Ken Zener with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

componenttext: And don't pick on the California folks there.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: I love California. We're making a lot of money in California now.
componenttext: I love California. We're making a lot of money in California now.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: You can make more. All right. So look all the stocks that are reporting today across all the categories, record margins, record demand, limited supply, right? What's different this cycle is that we have very low interest rates into COVID, very high consum
componenttext:
You can make more. All right. So look all the stocks that are reporting today across all the categories, record margins, record demand, limited supply, right? What's different this cycle is that we have very low interest rates into COVID, very high consumer credit, right? Governments are printing all the money. And structurally, in housing, there's a very high propensity for institutional buyers, right? I mean it's coming from builders like you, your other large builders, something $5 billion, $6 billion portfolios all the time, buying 15,000, 20,000 unit properties. 
So look, I think you guys obviously have the best business model in many ways, and you're working on your land supply. So I understand all that. But where are -- as an operator, I mean, your WIP is less capitalized, it is an inventory divided by WIP, than it is historically. And your leverage is so low. I mean, what is -- what are you going to look for, I guess, to see when -- yes. It seems like you're over-earning. Obviously, you guys -- there's nothing that will indicate your margins are going down. You're actually going up. But I mean, what do you think it will be there? Are you looking -- how are you looking at the existing side? How are you looking at people bidding on properties that's maybe not an individual investor but all this institutional money that's coming because the cap rates are still good? What is it that you're looking at separate from the operations on the macro that causes you -- Yes, I don't know? If there's a factor to look at rather than the operational side. That's it.

headline: D.R. Horton, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2021
componenttextpreview: I think from a -- looking at what macro storm clouds might be, the things that might happen in the next 6 months or a year that we never anticipated, like a worldwide pandemic that we didn't anticipate 2 years ago, there are certainly things like that, th
componenttext:
I think from a -- looking at what macro storm clouds might be, the things that might happen in the next 6 months or a year that we never anticipated, like a worldwide pandemic that we didn't anticipate 2 years ago, there are certainly things like that, that can happen that could impact the business. Rising interest rates always are a significant cost input into the value of the homes and the monthly payment. We monitor obviously that very closely and looking at affordability. I think Jessica touched on it before with 2 points and the stress testing we did the backlog. The backlog can withstand some interest rate upward movement right now. 
In addition, the DTI, the debt-to-income levels we're seeing in our borrowers this most recent quarter actually ticking down a little bit despite the average loan size going up. So the credit quality of our buyers are good. Looking at our for-sale communities, the vast majority of the buyers of those homes are owner-occupied homes. We don't have any institutional relational outtake programs in our for-sale communities. Our institutional focus would be on the build-to-rent communities, which are separate and apart from the for-sale side of our business. 
It's hard to know all the things that may change in the future, Ken. But one thing we do focus on and have focused on for many years is maintaining a very strong flexible balance sheet, as you said, where we have great low leverage, strong equity capitalization and very good liquidity. That allows us to take advantage of the market conditions as they change and continue to consolidate market share, especially at a local level where we can turn that local market share leverage and do outperformance.
